awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Development of High-Resolution Finite-Volume Methods for Systems of Nonlinear Time-Dependent PDEs
awd_abstract_narration:
The project is aimed at developing highly accurate, efficient and robust numerical methods for systems of nonlinear time-dependent PDEs, with particular reference to multidimensional hyperbolic systems of conservation/balance laws and related problems. The principal part of the proposed research will be focused on the development of new finite-volume methods that will provide an improved resolution of linear contact waves and incorporate new techniques for solving problems involving complicated nonlinear wave phenomena and blowing up/spiky solutions. The proposed methods will be applied to a variety of nonlinear problems, among which are systems of gas dynamics, nonlinear elasticity and acoustics systems, modern traffic flow models, several chemotaxis and bioconvection models, and others. These problems will be studied in the most challenging cases of high space dimensions, complex geometries and moving interfaces. For each problem, a high-resolution finite-volume scheme will be systematically derived in a way that the main properties satisfied by the underlying system of PDEs will be also satisfied on the discrete level. One of the key features of the new schemes will be their nonlinear stability, which will be ensured by ability of the scheme to preserve positivity of such physical quantities as density. To achieve this goal, several high-order positivity preserving techniques will be explored.

Besides providing the examples that corroborate the analytical approach, the foregoing applications are of a substantial independent value for a broad class of problems arising in today's science including geophysics, meteorology, astrophysics, semiconductors, traffic flows, image processing, financial and biological modeling and many other areas. Development of modern high-resolution finite-volume methods as well as of supplementary techniques is essential for solving many practically important problems, some of which are currently out of reach because the existing numerical methods are either inefficient/inaccurate or not applicable at all.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE ADMINISTRATORS OF TULANE EDUCATIONAL FUND

por.por_cntn:
The PI has designed a novel numerical method for tracking-type optimal control problems that appear in a variety of applications that offer control or design possibilities, such as the design of airfoils, ducts and turbine blades, the control of traffic flow or the identification of parameters in chromatography or hydrodynamics;

The PI has studied several chemotaxis models includng a chemotaxis-fluid system designed to model modestly diluted cell-suspensions. The considered system couples a convective chemotaxis system for the oxygen-consuming and oxytactic bacteria with the incompressible Navier-Stokes equations subject to a gravitational force proportional to the relative surplus of the cell-density compared to the water-density. The PI has derived a high-resolution vorticity-based hybrid finite-volume finite-difference scheme and used it to investigate the nonlinear dynamics of the studied system. The PI has conducted numerical experiments, which illustrate (i) formation of sinking plumes, (ii) possible merging of neighboring plumes and (iii) convergence towards numerically stable stationary plumes;

The PI has developed a well-balanced numerical method for the Euler equations with gravity, which are used to model astrophysical and atmospheric phenomena in many fields including supernova explosions, (solar) climate modeling and weather forecasting.

The PI has studied compressible gas dynamics coupled with a suspended particulate phase ("dust") having small volume fraction but possibly large density per unit volume relative to the gas. Dusty gas flows arise in many applications, from industrial processes to geophysical flows. One particular application, which was the original motivation for the research, is the study of volcanic ash plumes and pyroclastic flows. The PI has developed a numerical method for simulating dusty gas flows and tested it in a number of experiments. The developed approach may be directly applicable in other contexts as well. 

In numerical simulation, accounting for uncertainties in input quantities (such as model parameters, initial and boundary conditions, and geometry) is an important issue, especially in risk analysis, safety, and design. Assuming that these input quantities can be parametrized by random variables with known distribution functions, the question is to quantify the resulting uncertainty in the numerical solution. Uncertainty quantification provides for instance numerical error bars that make the comparison with experimental observations easier and therefore facilitate the evaluation of physical models. Moreover, they enable to identify the uncertain parameters that should be measured or controlled with more accuracy because they have the most significant impact on the solution. Furthermore, they allow for the assessment of the reliability level that can be attached to computations. The PI has also considered the compressible Euler equations with uncertainties and designed a novel numerical approach, which allows for reliable and efficient uncertainty quantification.

The interface tracking method proposed by the PI has been incorporated into an open source software package DUNE, developed at the University of Freiburg, Germany. DUNE is a modular toolbox for solving PDEs with grid-based methods. The package has been widely used in both academic institution and industry.

por.por_txt_cntn:
The  PI has designed a novel numerical method for tracking-type optimal  control problems that appear in a variety of applications that offer  control or design possibilities, such as the design of airfoils, ducts  and turbine blades, the control of traffic flow or the identification of  parameters in chromatography or hydrodynamics;
 
 The  PI has studied several chemotaxis models includng a chemotaxis-fluid  system designed to model modestly diluted cell-suspensions. The  considered system couples a convective chemotaxis system for the  oxygen-consuming and oxytactic bacteria with the incompressible  Navier-Stokes equations subject to a gravitational force proportional to  the relative surplus of the cell-density compared to the water-density.  The PI has derived a high-resolution vorticity-based hybrid  finite-volume finite-difference scheme and used it to investigate the  nonlinear dynamics of the studied system. The PI has conducted numerical  experiments, which illustrate (i) formation of sinking plumes, (ii)  possible merging of neighboring plumes and (iii) convergence towards  numerically stable stationary plumes;
 
 The PI  has developed a well-balanced numerical method for the Euler equations  with gravity, which are used to model astrophysical and atmospheric  phenomena in many fields including supernova explosions, (solar) climate  modeling and weather forecasting.

The  PI has studied compressible gas dynamics coupled with a suspended  particulate phase ("dust") having small volume fraction but possibly  large density per unit volume relative to the gas. Dusty gas flows arise  in many applications, from industrial processes to geophysical flows.  One particular application, which was the original motivation for the  research, is the study of volcanic ash plumes and pyroclastic flows. The  PI has developed a numerical method for simulating dusty gas flows and  tested it in a number of experiments. The developed approach may be  directly applicable in other contexts as well. 







In  numerical simulation, accounting for uncertainties in input quantities  (such as model parameters, initial and boundary conditions, and  geometry) is an important issue, especially in risk analysis, safety,  and design. Assuming that these input quantities can be parametrized by  random variables with known distribution functions, the question is to  quantify the resulting uncertainty in the numerical solution.  Uncertainty quantification provides for instance numerical error bars  that make the comparison with experimental observations easier and  therefore facilitate the evaluation of physical models. Moreover, they  enable to identify the uncertain parameters that should be measured or  controlled with more accuracy because they have the most significant  impact on the solution. Furthermore, they allow for the assessment of  the reliability level that can be attached to computations. The PI has  also considered the compressible Euler equations with uncertainties and  designed a novel numerical approach, which allows for reliable and  efficient uncertainty quantification.







The  interface tracking method proposed by the PI has been incorporated into  an open source software package DUNE, developed at the University of  Freiburg, Germany. DUNE is a modular toolbox for solving PDEs with  grid-based methods. The package has been widely used in both academic  institution and industry.
 
 The project greatly  facilitated the offering of the training graduate students and a special  topic course.The results of the research have been widely disseminated  by putting the preprints on the web via the PI's home pages, by making  the developed codes available to other researchers, by presentations of  the obtained results at national and international meetings by the PI,  and by organizing sessions and programs at conferences and institutes in  related subjects.
